title: Ezekiel Chapter 1 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 1 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 1 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 1.

questions.question: Where was Ezekiel when he saw visions of God?
options: By the river Chebar
In Jerusalem
On Mount Sinai
In Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: By the river Chebar
questions.explanation: Ezekiel was among the captives by the river of Chebar when he saw visions of God, as stated in Ezekiel 1:1.

questions.question: In which year of King Jehoiachin's captivity did Ezekiel receive the word of the LORD?
options: Fifth year
First year
Tenth year
Third year
questions.correctAnswer: Fifth year
questions.explanation: The word of the LORD came to Ezekiel in the fifth year of king Jehoiachin's captivity, as noted in Ezekiel 1:2.

questions.question: Who is Ezekiel identified as in Ezekiel 1:3?
options: A priest, son of Buzi
A prophet, son of David
A king, son of Jehoiachin
A scribe, son of Aaron
questions.correctAnswer: A priest, son of Buzi
questions.explanation: Ezekiel is described as a priest, the son of Buzi, in Ezekiel 1:3.

questions.question: What came out of the north as Ezekiel looked, according to Ezekiel 1:4?
options: A whirlwind with a great cloud and fire
A river of water
A bright star
A mountain covered with snow
questions.correctAnswer: A whirlwind with a great cloud and fire
questions.explanation: Ezekiel saw a whirlwind coming out of the north, a great cloud, and fire infolding itself, as described in Ezekiel 1:4.

questions.question: How many faces did each of the four living creatures have?
options: Four faces
Two faces
One face
Three faces
questions.correctAnswer: Four faces
questions.explanation: Each living creature had four faces as stated in Ezekiel 1:6.

questions.question: What was the appearance of the feet of the living creatures?
options: Like the sole of a calf's foot, sparkling like burnished brass
Like eagle talons
Like lion paws
Like human feet
questions.correctAnswer: Like the sole of a calf's foot, sparkling like burnished brass
questions.explanation: Their feet were straight and the sole was like that of a calf's foot, sparkling like burnished brass, as described in Ezekiel 1:7.

questions.question: True or False: The wings of the living creatures were joined one to another and they turned as they went.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The creatures' wings were joined one to another and they did not turn when they went; they went straight forward, as stated in Ezekiel 1:9.

questions.question: Which of the following was NOT one of the faces of the living creatures?
options: Serpent
Man
Lion
Ox
questions.correctAnswer: Serpent
questions.explanation: The faces described were of a man, lion, ox, and eagle; serpent is not mentioned, as per Ezekiel 1:10.

questions.question: What covered the bodies of the living creatures?
options: Two of their wings
A cloak of feathers
Their four faces
A robe of light
questions.correctAnswer: Two of their wings
questions.explanation: Two wings of every creature covered their bodies, while the other two were stretched upward, as stated in Ezekiel 1:11.

questions.question: How did the living creatures move according to Ezekiel 1:12?
options: Straight forward without turning
In circles turning often
Backward and forward
Randomly in all directions
questions.correctAnswer: Straight forward without turning
questions.explanation: The creatures went straight forward wherever the spirit was to go and did not turn, according to Ezekiel 1:12.

questions.question: True or False: The appearance of the living creatures was like burning coals of fire and lamps with lightning going forth from the fire.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Their appearance was like burning coals of fire and lamps, with fire and lightning going forth, as stated in Ezekiel 1:13.

questions.question: What was unique about the wheels beside the living creatures?
options: They appeared as a wheel in the middle of a wheel
They were made of gold
They had no rims
They were stationary
questions.correctAnswer: They appeared as a wheel in the middle of a wheel
questions.explanation: The wheels had the likeness of a wheel within a wheel, as described in Ezekiel 1:16.

questions.question: What filled the rims of the wheels?
options: Eyes all around
Jewels
Fire
Feathers
questions.correctAnswer: Eyes all around
questions.explanation: Their rims were full of eyes all around, according to Ezekiel 1:18.

questions.question: True or False: The spirit of the living creatures was also in the wheels, causing them to move together.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The spirit of the living creatures was in the wheels, and they moved together as one, as explained in Ezekiel 1:20.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Above the firmament over the heads of the living creatures was the likeness of a _______, as the appearance of a sapphire stone.
options: throne
cloud
mountain
river
questions.correctAnswer: throne
questions.explanation: Ezekiel saw the likeness of a throne above the firmament, resembling a sapphire stone, as described in Ezekiel 1:26.

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 1 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 1 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Ezekiel 1, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God’s presence in difficult times?
options: God reveals His glory even in captivity and hardship
Trials mean God has abandoned His people
Only prophets can see God’s visions
Difficult times are for personal punishment only
questions.correctAnswer: God reveals His glory even in captivity and hardship
questions.explanation: Ezekiel received visions of God's glory while among captives (Ezekiel 1:1-3), showing that God is present and sovereign even in difficult circumstances, encouraging trust and faith.

questions.question: How does the description of the four living creatures in Ezekiel 1 teach us about God’s multifaceted nature and call us to humility in service?
options: The creatures’ multiple faces represent God’s complex power and holiness, calling us to humble obedience
The creatures show God is distant and unapproachable
The creatures represent human authority over angels
The creatures suggest God changes His character often
questions.correctAnswer: The creatures’ multiple faces represent God’s complex power and holiness, calling us to humble obedience
questions.explanation: The creatures had four faces (man, lion, ox, eagle) symbolizing diverse aspects of God’s majesty and authority (Ezekiel 1:5-10), reminding believers to approach God with reverence and humility.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with staying focused in prayer and obedience. What does Ezekiel 1 teach about following the Spirit’s leading?
options: The living creatures and wheels followed the Spirit without turning aside, showing the need for steadfast spiritual focus
The creatures often changed directions showing flexibility over focus
The wheels moved independently of the creatures
The Spirit leads only during prophetic visions
questions.correctAnswer: The living creatures and wheels followed the Spirit without turning aside, showing the need for steadfast spiritual focus
questions.explanation: Ezekiel describes the creatures and wheels going straight where the Spirit led without turning (Ezekiel 1:9, 17, 20-21), illustrating the importance of obedience and focus in spiritual life.

questions.question: How can the imagery of the wheels full of eyes in Ezekiel 1 inspire a believer’s work ethic and integrity?
options: The eyes symbolize God’s all-seeing presence, encouraging honesty and accountability in all work
The eyes represent human surveillance only
The wheels suggest work is irrelevant to faith
The eyes mean only spiritual leaders are watched
questions.correctAnswer: The eyes symbolize God’s all-seeing presence, encouraging honesty and accountability in all work
questions.explanation: The wheels were full of eyes (Ezekiel 1:18), symbolizing God’s omniscience and reminding believers to work with integrity as God sees all actions.

questions.question: A believer desires to grow in worship and reverence. What lesson does Ezekiel 1 provide about responding to God’s glory?
options: Falling on one’s face in awe is an appropriate response to God’s glory
Ignoring God’s presence shows spiritual maturity
Only priests should show reverence
God’s glory is only seen in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Falling on one’s face in awe is an appropriate response to God’s glory
questions.explanation: Ezekiel fell on his face when he saw the glory of the LORD (Ezekiel 1:28), teaching believers to respond with humility and reverence to God’s manifest presence.

questions.question: How does the vision of fire and brightness in Ezekiel 1 encourage perseverance through trials?
options: The fire signifies God’s purifying presence, reminding believers that trials refine faith
Fire means destruction without hope
Brightness shows only external success matters
The vision is only symbolic of fear
questions.correctAnswer: The fire signifies God’s purifying presence, reminding believers that trials refine faith
questions.explanation: The vision included fire and brightness (Ezekiel 1:4, 13, 27) symbolizing God’s purifying power, encouraging believers to endure hardships as God’s refining process.

questions.question: A believer is unsure about how to serve effectively in church. Based on Ezekiel 1, what principle about unity and cooperation can you share?
options: The creatures’ wings were joined together, symbolizing unity and coordinated service
Each creature served independently without connection
Service in church should be competitive
Unity is not important in spiritual matters
questions.correctAnswer: The creatures’ wings were joined together, symbolizing unity and coordinated service
questions.explanation: Ezekiel describes the wings of the creatures joined one to another (Ezekiel 1:8, 11, 23), illustrating the value of unity and harmony in serving God’s people.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 1 teach about God’s omnipresence and the believer’s need for constant awareness of His presence?
options: The wheels full of eyes and spirit within them show God’s presence everywhere, calling for continuous godly living
God’s presence is limited to holy places only
Believers should only be aware of God’s presence during prayer
God’s spirit is with only the prophets
questions.correctAnswer: The wheels full of eyes and spirit within them show God’s presence everywhere, calling for continuous godly living
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:18, 20-21 shows the wheels full of eyes and the spirit of living creatures in them, symbolizing God’s all-encompassing presence, encouraging believers to live with integrity always.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel’s vision teaches that God’s glory is only revealed to a select few in special moments.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: While Ezekiel had a special vision (Ezekiel 1:1-3), the chapter reveals God’s glory can be revealed even in captivity and hardship, encouraging all believers to seek and trust God’s presence.

questions.question: True or False: The living creatures in Ezekiel’s vision turned in different directions as they moved.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The creatures went straight forward without turning as the spirit led them (Ezekiel 1:9, 12, 17), teaching believers to walk steadily in God’s guidance without wavering.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The sound of the living creatures’ wings was like the noise of _______, symbolizing the powerful voice of God encouraging perseverance.
options: great waters
thunder
fire
wind
questions.correctAnswer: great waters
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:24 compares the noise of the wings to great waters and the voice of the Almighty, illustrating God’s powerful presence that strengthens believers.

questions.question: How does the description of the firmament in Ezekiel 1 inspire believers to recognize God’s protection and order in their lives?
options: The firmament is like terrible crystal stretched over the creatures, symbolizing God’s protective presence and order
The firmament shows chaos in God’s creation
It represents a barrier separating God from people
It means God’s presence is limited
questions.correctAnswer: The firmament is like terrible crystal stretched over the creatures, symbolizing God’s protective presence and order
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:22 describes the firmament as crystal over the creatures, symbolizing God’s sustaining and orderly presence, encouraging believers to trust His protection.

questions.question: In parenting or teaching others about God, how can Ezekiel 1’s vision of the throne and the man-like figure help explain God’s majesty and intimate knowledge of humanity?
options: God’s throne and the man-likeness above it show His sovereign majesty and personal care for people
God is distant and uninvolved in human affairs
God’s image is only symbolic with no personal relevance
God’s throne is inaccessible and unapproachable
questions.correctAnswer: God’s throne and the man-likeness above it show His sovereign majesty and personal care for people
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:26-27 depicts a throne with the likeness of a man above it, showing both God’s majesty and His personal presence with His people, encouraging believers to trust and relate to Him.

questions.question: How does the imagery of the creatures covering their bodies with two wings each in Ezekiel 1 teach about humility and reverence in Christian life?
options: Covering their bodies with wings shows humility and reverence before God, modeling how believers should approach Him
The wings symbolize pride and self-exaltation
Covering bodies means hiding from God’s presence
It teaches believers to remain distant from God
questions.correctAnswer: Covering their bodies with wings shows humility and reverence before God, modeling how believers should approach Him
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:11, 23 describes creatures covering their bodies with wings, symbolizing reverence and humility, attitudes Christians should cultivate when worshiping and serving God.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 1 teach about the importance of listening to God’s voice amid the noise of life?
options: The voice from the firmament over the creatures calls believers to attentive listening and obedience
God’s voice is always loud and unmistakable
Believers should ignore God’s voice in difficult times
Only prophets hear God’s voice
questions.correctAnswer: The voice from the firmament over the creatures calls believers to attentive listening and obedience
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:25 describes a voice from the firmament, encouraging believers to be attentive and obedient to God’s communication amidst life’s distractions.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 1 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 1.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'four faces' described on the living creatures in Ezekiel 1, and how do they relate to other biblical symbols?
options: They represent the four Gospels and symbolize the completeness of God's revelation
They indicate four tribes of Israel and their unity
They symbolize the four corners of the earth and God's sovereignty over all
They reflect the four seasons and God's control over nature
questions.correctAnswer: They represent the four Gospels and symbolize the completeness of God's revelation
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:10 describes the four faces of man, lion, ox, and eagle, which Christian tradition often interprets as symbols for the four Gospels (Matthew, Mark, Luke, John), indicating the fullness of divine revelation.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 1:4, the whirlwind, fire, and brightness are described coming from the north. What is the theological significance of the north in this context?
options: The north is traditionally seen as the direction of divine judgment and God's majestic presence
The north is the direction of exile and destruction
The north represents chaos and evil forces
The north is associated with the temple and holiness
questions.correctAnswer: The north is traditionally seen as the direction of divine judgment and God's majestic presence
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:4 associates the north with the coming of God’s glory, consistent with biblical tradition where divine judgment and presence often come from the north, a motif also seen in Isaiah and Jeremiah.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Ezekiel 1:16 where the wheels are described as 'a wheel in the middle of a wheel'?
options: Chiasmus
Parallelism
Symbolic imagery
Allegory
questions.correctAnswer: Symbolic imagery
questions.explanation: The phrase 'a wheel in the middle of a wheel' in Ezekiel 1:16 functions as symbolic imagery emphasizing the complex and mysterious nature of divine mobility and omnipresence.

questions.question: How does the description of the 'firmament' in Ezekiel 1:22 connect with ancient Near Eastern cosmology?
options: It reflects the concept of a solid dome separating the heavens and the earth
It symbolizes the chaotic waters above the sky
It represents the boundary of the underworld
It denotes the earthly temple's roof
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the concept of a solid dome separating the heavens and the earth
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:22’s reference to the firmament as 'terrible crystal' aligns with ancient Near Eastern ideas of a solid dome separating the heavenly waters from the earth, highlighting continuity in cosmological imagery.

questions.question: Which New Testament vision parallels Ezekiel's vision of the living creatures and wheels, indicating continuity in apocalyptic imagery?
options: Revelation 4
Daniel 7
Matthew 24
Acts 2
questions.correctAnswer: Revelation 4
questions.explanation: Revelation 4 depicts four living creatures around God’s throne with multiple eyes and wings, paralleling Ezekiel 1:5-21 and showing the continuity of apocalyptic symbolism.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'burning coals of fire' and 'lightning' that go up and down among the living creatures in Ezekiel 1:13-14?
options: They symbolize divine energy and the presence of God's power and holiness
They represent the destruction of Israel's enemies
They signify the purification of the temple
They indicate natural phenomena observed by Ezekiel
questions.correctAnswer: They symbolize divine energy and the presence of God's power and holiness
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:13-14 uses fire and lightning imagery to depict the dynamic and powerful presence of God, a common biblical metaphor for divine holiness and energy.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 1:26-28, the 'likeness of a throne' and 'appearance of a man' are described. How does this prefigure the concept of the divine Logos in later Christian theology?
options: It foreshadows the incarnation of Christ as the visible manifestation of God
It indicates an angelic being mediating between God and man
It is a symbolic vision with no later theological connection
It represents the human priesthood's authority
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows the incarnation of Christ as the visible manifestation of God
questions.explanation: The throne and man-like figure in Ezekiel 1:26-28 are often interpreted as a prefiguration of the Logos, the Word made flesh in John 1, emphasizing God’s revelation in human form.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 1:9 and 1:17, the living creatures and the wheels could turn independently of each other during their movement.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:9 and 1:17 state that both the living creatures and the wheels 'turned not when they went,' indicating they moved in perfect unison without independent turning.

questions.question: What cultural or historical context helps explain Ezekiel's location 'by the river Chebar' in Ezekiel 1:1-3?
options: Ezekiel was among the Jewish exiles in Babylonian captivity near the Chebar canal
He was at the temple in Jerusalem by the Jordan River
He was in Egypt during the Exodus
He was in Assyria during the reign of Sennacherib
questions.correctAnswer: Ezekiel was among the Jewish exiles in Babylonian captivity near the Chebar canal
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:1-3 situates him by the river Chebar, historically known as a canal in Babylon, indicating his status as a captive during the Babylonian exile.

questions.question: What is the meaning of the description of the feet of the living creatures as 'like the sole of a calf's foot' and 'sparkled like burnished brass' in Ezekiel 1:7?
options: It signifies strength, purity, and divine refinement
It is a metaphor for humility and meekness
It indicates the creatures were animals of the field
It refers to the creatures' ability to walk silently
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies strength, purity, and divine refinement
questions.explanation: The feet imagery in Ezekiel 1:7 combines the solidity of calf’s feet with the brilliance of burnished brass, symbolizing power and holiness.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 1 demonstrate the use of typology in biblical literature?
options: The vision typifies God's glory and presence, foreshadowing the Messiah and eschatological restoration
It typifies the fall of Jerusalem and exile exclusively
It is a literal description with no typological meaning
It typifies the Israelite kingship alone
questions.correctAnswer: The vision typifies God's glory and presence, foreshadowing the Messiah and eschatological restoration
questions.explanation: Ezekiel's vision serves as typology by representing God's transcendent glory and hints at future fulfillment in Christ and the ultimate restoration of creation.

questions.question: Which Hebrew word describing the creatures' movement in Ezekiel 1:12 and 1:20 highlights their spiritual obedience and unity with God's will?
options: Ruach (spirit/wind)
Shema (hear)
Chesed (lovingkindness)
Emet (truth)
questions.correctAnswer: Ruach (spirit/wind)
questions.explanation: The term 'spirit' (Hebrew 'ruach') in Ezekiel 1:12 and 1:20 emphasizes the creatures’ movement directed by the divine spirit, symbolizing obedience and unity with God’s purpose.

questions.question: What is the literary significance of the repeated phrase 'when those went, these went' in Ezekiel 1:21?
options: It emphasizes the perfect harmony and coordination between the living creatures and the wheels
It highlights the confusion in the vision
It indicates a division among the creatures
It introduces a chiasm focusing on God's throne
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes the perfect harmony and coordination between the living creatures and the wheels
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:21’s repetition underscores the seamless unity in motion between the creatures and the wheels, illustrating divine order and coordination.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 1:24, what does the noise of the creatures' wings resemble, and what might this symbolize?
options: The noise of great waters and the voice of the Almighty, symbolizing overwhelming divine majesty and presence
The sound of thunder, symbolizing judgment
The rustling of leaves, symbolizing peace
The roar of a lion, symbolizing power
questions.correctAnswer: The noise of great waters and the voice of the Almighty, symbolizing overwhelming divine majesty and presence
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:24 describes the wings' noise like 'great waters' and 'the voice of the Almighty,' conveying awe-inspiring divine power and majesty.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel 1:18 describes the wheels' rings as being 'full of _____ round about them four.'
options: eyes
fire
thunder
wings
questions.correctAnswer: eyes
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:18 states that the wheels' rings were 'full of eyes round about them four,' symbolizing divine awareness and omniscience.

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 1 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 1 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Ezekiel's vision, from which direction did the whirlwind come that heralded the appearance of the living creatures?
options: Out of the north
Out of the south
Out of the east
Out of the west
questions.correctAnswer: Out of the north
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:4 describes a whirlwind coming out of the north, a direction often symbolizing divine intervention or judgment (cf. Jeremiah 1:14; Nahum 1:3; Isaiah 14:13; Revelation 7:1).

questions.question: What is the significance of the four faces on each living creature in Ezekiel's vision?
options: Man, lion, ox, and eagle
Man, bear, lion, and eagle
Man, lion, serpent, and ox
Man, ox, eagle, and serpent
questions.correctAnswer: Man, lion, ox, and eagle
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:10 details the four faces representing different facets of creation and attributes of God’s majesty and power, paralleling the four living creatures in Revelation 4:7, symbolizing the fullness of God's creation and divine attributes.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel's vision, how many wings did each living creature have?
options: Four wings
Two wings
Six wings
Eight wings
questions.correctAnswer: Four wings
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:6 states each creature had four wings, which is consistent with seraphim in Isaiah 6:2 having six wings, representing a hierarchy of heavenly beings and their roles in worship and divine movement.

questions.question: What aspect of the living creatures' feet is highlighted in Ezekiel's description?
options: Their feet were straight and sparkled like burnished brass
Their feet were hoofed like a horse
Their feet were like bird talons
Their feet were covered in scales
questions.correctAnswer: Their feet were straight and sparkled like burnished brass
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:7 describes their feet as straight with soles like a calf’s foot, shining like burnished brass, symbolizing both purity and strength akin to the bronze altar in the tabernacle (cf. Exodus 27:1-2; Revelation 1:15).

questions.question: What does the 'wheel within a wheel' in Ezekiel's vision most likely symbolize?
options: The omnipresence and omnidirectionality of God's Spirit
The cyclical nature of history
The four corners of the earth
The unity of Israel and the nations
questions.correctAnswer: The omnipresence and omnidirectionality of God's Spirit
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:16-17 describes wheels intersecting that can move in any direction without turning, symbolizing God’s Spirit’s ability to move freely and sovereignly. This aligns with John 3:8 (Spirit like the wind), and Psalm 139:7-10 (God's omnipresence).

questions.question: What is the significance of the eyes all around the rims of the wheels in Ezekiel's vision?
options: Symbolizing God's all-seeing knowledge and omniscience
Representing the twelve tribes of Israel
Denoting angelic watchfulness over humanity
Indicating the seasons and times
questions.correctAnswer: Symbolizing God's all-seeing knowledge and omniscience
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:18 describes the rings full of eyes, which symbolize God's all-seeing nature, reminiscent of God's omniscience in Psalm 33:13-15 and Revelation 4:6-8 where the living creatures also have eyes all around, indicating divine awareness.

questions.question: How did Ezekiel describe the noise made by the wings of the living creatures when they moved?
options: Like the noise of great waters and the voice of the Almighty
Like the whisper of a gentle breeze
Like the sound of thunder
Like the roaring of a lion
questions.correctAnswer: Like the noise of great waters and the voice of the Almighty
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:24 compares the sound of the wings to great waters and the voice of the Almighty, linking God’s power and majesty with natural elements (cf. Psalm 29:3-4; Revelation 19:6).

questions.question: What was above the firmament over the heads of the living creatures in Ezekiel's vision?
options: The likeness of a throne with the appearance of a man upon it
A great crystal sea
A shining sun
A burning mountain
questions.correctAnswer: The likeness of a throne with the appearance of a man upon it
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:26 describes a throne above the firmament with the likeness of a man seated, symbolizing God's sovereign presence and glory, paralleling the throne vision in Daniel 7:9-10 and Revelation 4:2-3.

questions.question: What does the brightness and fire surrounding the figure on the throne symbolize in Ezekiel's vision?
options: The glory and holiness of God
The consuming judgment of God alone
The separation between God and creation
The presence of angelic hosts
questions.correctAnswer: The glory and holiness of God
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:27 describes fire and brightness around the figure, symbolizing God’s radiant holiness and glory (cf. Exodus 24:17; Psalm 104:2; Hebrews 1:3; Revelation 21:23).

questions.question: The rainbow-like brightness around the throne in Ezekiel’s vision is reminiscent of which biblical symbol?
options: The covenantal rainbow signifying God's mercy
The pillar of fire guiding Israel
The flaming sword guarding Eden
The burning bush
questions.correctAnswer: The covenantal rainbow signifying God's mercy
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:28 compares the brightness to a bow in a cloud, evoking God's covenantal mercy first revealed in Genesis 9:13-16 and later echoed in Revelation 4:3, underscoring God's faithfulness amid His glory.

questions.question: What role does the spirit play in the movement of the living creatures and the wheels in Ezekiel’s vision?
options: The spirit directs their movement and is present in the wheels
The spirit only moves the living creatures but not the wheels
The spirit is a separate entity not related to movement
The spirit is only symbolic and does not affect movement
questions.correctAnswer: The spirit directs their movement and is present in the wheels
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:20-21 states the spirit of the living creatures is in the wheels, and wherever the spirit goes, they go, illustrating divine sovereignty and the unity of God's Spirit with His creation (cf. John 3:8; Romans 8:14; Psalm 104:30).

questions.question: Where was Ezekiel when he received the vision of God’s glory in chapter 1?
options: Among the captives by the river Chebar
In the temple in Jerusalem
On Mount Sinai
In Babylonian palace
questions.correctAnswer: Among the captives by the river Chebar
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:1-3 situates Ezekiel among the exiles by the river Chebar in Babylonian territory, emphasizing God’s revelation comes even in exile and judgment (cf. Daniel 1:1-2; Jeremiah 29:4-7; Acts 7:58).

questions.question: The living creatures in Ezekiel’s vision had hands located where?
options: Under their wings on their four sides
At the end of their wings
Only on their front faces
No hands were visible
questions.correctAnswer: Under their wings on their four sides
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:8 specifies the living creatures had hands like those of a man under their wings on all sides, symbolizing both capability and divine agency (cf. Exodus 31:3; Colossians 1:29).

questions.question: How did Ezekiel respond when he saw the likeness of the glory of the LORD in his vision?
options: He fell upon his face and heard a voice speaking
He shouted aloud in praise
He ran away in fear
He immediately began to prophesy
questions.correctAnswer: He fell upon his face and heard a voice speaking
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:28 reveals that in response to God's glory, Ezekiel fell on his face, a common biblical posture of reverence and awe (cf. Exodus 34:8; Daniel 8:17; Revelation 1:17).

questions.question: What does the description of the firmament as 'the colour of terrible crystal' above the living creatures suggest about God’s glory?
options: It signifies the transcendent holiness and majesty of God
It represents God’s judgment upon the nations
It symbolizes the fragility of creation
It denotes the mystery of the heavens
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies the transcendent holiness and majesty of God
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 1:22 uses 'terrible crystal' to describe the firmament, conveying God's purity, holiness, and awe-inspiring majesty, consistent with descriptions of God's glory in Exodus 24:10 and Revelation 21:18.
